Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 Records and Photographs
Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union. Local 3 (Long Island City, N.Y.)
Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union. Local 3 (Long Island City, N.Y.)
Spratley, Carol Hofheinz
WAG 135
33.5 Linear Feet in 34 record cartons.
1902-1996 1955-1986 This collection contains the minutes, officers' papers, subject files and photographs files of the Bakery Confectionery and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3, including executive and grievance boards, general membership meetings as well as the papers of Presidents Frank Dutto, and Harry Lorber and Business Agent Michael Sandroff. Topics range from bargaining and arbitration to elections and anniversary dinners. There is information on specific bake shops from the small family-run shops to large corporate bakeries. Materials are primarily in English, with some materials in German and Yiddish.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Historical/Biographical Note
Bakers Union Local 3 was established in 1955 with the merger of locals 1, 3, 17, 164, 288, and 579. During the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union Convention of 1951, a resolution was passed to implement the merger of all New York bakery locals. Frequent jurisdictional disputes between rival locals were undermining the collective strength of bakers within the industry. Over a dozen local unions representing the interests of workers in the baking industry in New York took part in merger discussions sponsored by the International, but by 1955 only six of the participating unions consented to merge.
Beginning in the 1850s, New York played an important role in the evolution of the unionization of the trade. Owning to the large immigrant presence in New York, unions were originally established according to nationality. The German Bakers, the Jewish Bread Bakers, the French-Italian Bakers, the Spanish Bakers, among others, each existed as separate, independently organized entities. The result of these nationality-organized unions led to a frequent overlapping of jurisdictions within the Greater New York area. As early as 1937, a conference of the Bakery Workers International Union made an effort to address ongoing jurisdiction disputes by encouraging these disparate organizations to unify. Over the course of the next decade a series of mergers took place but nothing compared with the magnitude of the creation of Local 3 in 1955. With its establishment, Local 3 became a dominate force in the baking industry in New York and an important presence on the national front.
Under the dynamic leadership of its first president Frank Dutto, Local 3 would grapple with many challenges. Dutto had risen from the rank and file to become President first of Local 87, then Local 1, and subsequently Local 3. In 1958, Dutto appeared before the McClellan Committee in connection with the sponsorship of a fund-raising dinner for Bakery's vice-president, Max Kralstein. During these hearings Dutto invoked the 5th Amendment when questioned about his affiliation with the Communist Party. Throughout his remaining tenure as president, the taint of these hearings left him vulnerable. Perhaps the greatest upheaval during these years stemmed from corruption charges in the International. In 1958 the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union (BCW) was ousted by the AFL-CIO after International President James Cross was indicted for embezzlement. When the AFL chartered the American Bakery and Confectionery Workers' International (ABC), the baking industry fractured on an International level and locally there arose bitter jurisdictional disputes. The mending of this destabilizing division within the International became of primary concern to Local 3 under Dutto's stewardship. Local 3 would remain affiliated with the BCW but at the forefront of efforts to heal the split in the International. In 1959, Local 3 served a vital role in the formation of the Local Unions Reunification Committee. Reunification occurred in 1969 after a twelve-year struggle.
One of the chief concerns of the Local 3 executive board during its early years was the evolution of a standard contract and the development of uniform welfare and pension plans. With the merger of the six unions, Local 3 was now responsible for the negotiation of agreements with over 750 bakery employers each with differing provisions for wages, benefits and shop conditions. The turning point in the establishment of a standard contract came with the general strike of 1959 in which New York locals affiliated with both the BCW and the ABC struck in concert and remained off the job for over 3 months. With the settlement came the first uniform agreement in the baking industry in New York. Within months of the settlement, the union's new headquarters in Long Island City were completed and dedicated in June of 1959. In celebration of the event, Local 3 held its first Cake Show. Cake Shows would become annual events showcasing the talents of the skilled pastry, cake, and bread bakers. These occasions, along with the monthly publication of "Local 3 News," served to organize and bolster the membership of the growing union.
With the death of Frank Dutto in 1969, the former Secretary-Treasurer Harry Rubenstein took over the presidency and served from 1970 to 1973. These years brought a series of new mergers with Local 3 by other unions that sought greater bargaining strength and unity. By the end of Rubenstein's tenure, Matzoh-Noodle Local 269, Jersey Local 167, Bagel Local 338, and Perth Amboy Local 190 had all merged with Local 3. In 1973 the most significant merger since 1955 occurred when the powerful Cake Bakers Union Local 51 merged with Local 3. Jurisdictional disputes that had plagued these rival unions were brought to an end with this merger. Under the terms of the agreement Rubenstein retired and Harry Lorber, former Secretary-Treasurer of Local 51, assumed the position of President of Local 3.
Lorber served as president for the next 16 years, until 1989. Trained as a lawyer, Lorber was a member of the International General Executive Board, chairman of the New York Union Label and Service Trades organization, and chairman of the Baking Industry Labor-Management Apprenticeship Council. In addition he was the chairman of both the Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, and of the Local 3 Welfare and Pension Fund. During this era the Union and the baking industry would undergo great changes. Issues related to automation and corporate manufacturing dominated the 1970s and 1980s, as evidenced by the protracted contract negotiations with corporate giants such as Drakes and Entenmann's.
In 1989 Lorber retired and was succeeded by Secretary-Treasurer Ernst Schenkman in December of that year. Following the sudden death of Schenkman in a car accident one month later in January of 1990, the then Secretary-Treasurer Narciso Martas became the fourth President of Local 3.
Scope and Content Note
This collection contains the minutes, correspondence and chronological files of Locals 1, 3, 17, 164, 388, and 579, including executive and grievance boards, general membership meetings as well as the papers of Presidents Frank Dutto, and Harry Lorber and Business Agent Michael Sandroff. Also included in the collection are documents on standard contract negotiations as well as collective bargaining negotiations between individual shops and corporate entities. General files include records pertaining to by-laws, elections, legal disputes and grievances, the Cross indictment, and union label samples, amongst others. Souvenir programs and photographs from a variety of locals are also included.
Arrangement
Material in Series I is grouped by organizations and arranged chronologically within each grouping. Material in Series II is arranged alphabetically and chronologically. Series III is arranged chronologically, and Series IV though VIII are arranged alphabetically. Series IX has not been arranged by an archivist.
The records are organized into the following series:
Series I: Minutes, 1920-1984
Series II: Officers' Papers, 1946-1987
Series III: Bargaining and Arbitration, 1954-1987
Series IV: Shop Files, 1964-1989
Series V: Local 3, Subjects, 1954-1989
Series VI: Welfare and Pension Fund, 1955-1988
Series VII: General Files, 1902-1978
Series VIII: Souvenir Programs, 1930-1993
Series IX: Photographs, 1950-1990s
Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
New Yorkers at Work Oral History Collection (OH 001) contains interviews with members and officers of Bakers Local 3
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for most materials in this collection, created by the Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
Any rights for non-print materials (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Bakery, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 were transferred to New York University in 1996 by the Bakery, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3. Permission to publish or reproduce non-print materials in this collection must be secured from Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630.
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 Records and Photographs; WAG 135; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by the Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, AFL-CIO - Local 3 in 1996. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1996.017 and 1996.018.
A gift of a dues ledger from Local 6 was donated by Carol Hofheinz in August 2012. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.026.
Processing Information
The records were transferred by archivist Janet Greene from the Local headquarters at 41-07 Crescent Street, Long Island City, N.Y., to the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives in June 1996. A grant from the National Historic Publications and Records Commission (NHPRC) made the acquisition and processing possible.
Photographs separated from this collection during processing were established as a separate collection, the Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 Photographs (PHOTOS 108). In 2013, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the Bakery, Confectionery, and Tobacco Workers International Union, Local 3 Records and Photographs (WAG 135). In 2018, the civil rights exhibit, separated from the original collection, was integrated into Series IX: Photographs.

Series I: Minutes302981920-1984
Scope and Contents note
This series contains the minutes of five of the original six unions (Locals 1, 3, 17, 164, 579) that merged to create Local 3 in 1955 as well as a number of other local unions that subsequently merged with Local 3. The locals are arranged in numerically ascending order. Some of the minutes from the earlier years are in English, Yiddish and German (consult Box & Folder List) and reflect the multi-ethnic make-up of the trade. Within this series can also be found the minutes and transcripts related to pre-merger meetings, and included are the minutes of the Baking Industry Labor-Management Apprenticeship Council of Greater New York on which Harry Lorber served. (Note: The 1950-1951 minutes of Local 17 were received in disarray. The precise original order is unclear, but approximate order by month has been restored).Local 1, Amalgamated Food Workers (German)30406Aug 1920 - Jun 192711

Scope and Contents note
This series contains the papers of Presidents Frank Dutto and Harry Lorber and includes two slim folders of the papers of Michael (Mac) Sandroff who served as Business Agent and Editor of the "Local 3 News" from 1955 until his retirement. Unfortunately the absence of many of Dutto's papers in the Collection belies his extensive activities. Of particular interest is an election leaflet from 1947 bearing his picture, and a map with the location of his cemetery plot. The bulk of the material in this series belongs to Lorber. In addition to general files and correspondence related to his activities with Locals 3 and 51, Lorber's papers document his presence at a score of hearings as a member of the International General Executive Board, as well as his involvement with the Baking Industry Labor-Management Apprenticeship Council. He was often called upon as a public speaker and a folder of his speeches can be found in this series.Dutto Papers, Articles and Biographical Information302971946-1969101Dutto Papers, Election Leaflet302961947102Dutto Papers, General Files30295103Dutto Papers, "City of Hope" Program302941969104Dutto Papers, Specialty Local Wholesalers302931969105Dutto Papers, Map of Dutto Grave Site302921969106Lorber Papers, Articles and Biographical Information302911960-1979107Lorber Papers, General Files and Correspondence302901947-1952108Lorber Papers, General Files and Correspondence302891959-1970109Lorber Papers, General Files and Correspondence302881973-19741010Lorber Papers, General Files and Correspondence3028719751011Lorber Papers, General Files and Correspondence30286Jan 1976 - Scope and Contents note
This series contains Local 3 standard contracts, agreements and negotiation notes. Also included at the end of this series are four files of notes and contracts pertaining to Locals 51, 153, 579 and the Specialty Bakery Owners of America. Included in these files can be found the negotiation notes of Frank Dutto, Harry Lorber and Michael Sandroff. (Note: For the arbitration between Local 3 and particular shops, consult Series IV: Shop Files.)Standard Contracts and Agreements302431956-1959121Standard Contracts and Agreements, Folder 1302421960-1965122Standard Contracts and Agreements, Folder 2302411960-1965123Standard Contracts and Agreements302401965-1968124Standard Contracts and Agreements302391968-1971125Standard Contracts and Agreements302381971-1974126Standard Contracts and Agreements302371975-1981127Standard Contracts and Agreements302361980-1989128Standard Contract Negotiations302351965129Standard Contract Negotiations3023419671210Standard Contract Negotiations3023319681211Standard Contract Negotiations3023219711212Standard Contract Negotiations302311972-19731213Standard Contract Negotiations3023019741214Standard Contract Negotiations3022919751215Standard Contract Negotiations, Retail Stipulations-Signed Copies3022819751216Standard Contract Negotiations, Wage Comparisons302271973-19771217Standard Contract Negotiations3022619781218Standard Contract Negotiations3022519811219Standard Contract Negotiations302241982-19831220Standard Contract Negotiations3022319841221Standard Contract Negotiations302221986-19871222Standard Contracts and Agreements, Local 51302211968-19711223Contract Negotiations, Office Employees, Local 153302201968-19751224Standard Contracts and Agreements, Local 5793021919541225Standard Contract Negotiations, Specialty Bakery Owners of America3021819681226Series IV: Shop Files297781964-1989
Scope and Contents note
All materials dealing with contract negotiation and disputes pertaining to a particular shop or company can be found in these files. Represented here are Local 3's bargaining sessions and agreements with small family-run bake shops, as well as protracted negotiations with corporate entities such as Drakes, Entenmann's and Ellio's Pizza House. In 1974 fierce negotiations took place between union and management at Ellio's -- a tri-lingual shop. Of particular interest are the leaflets in English, Greek, and Spanish that were generated during the conflict. Matzoh-Noodle Shops, Bagel Shops, and the New Jersey Division held separate collective bargaining sessions and files document these negotiations. In a sub-series called "Shops Closed" are the records that the union kept from 1964 - 1976 of shops that either went out of business or ended their union affiliation.Shop Files, Route Ledger Code List302161975131Abraham Kosher Bread Shop302151981-1982132American Bakeries Corporation302141979-1981133Anbar Bake Shop, Inc.302131982134Arnold Bakers, Inc,302121972-1974135Aster Nut Production, Inc.302111974136Au Bon Pain Corp.302101983137Augies Bakery Shop302091983138Au P'tit Pain, Inc.302081985139Bagel Chips, Inc.3020719851310Bagel Division, Collective Bargaining302061972-19761311Bagel Division, Collective Bargaining-Negotiation Notes (H. Scope and Contents note
This series contains election fliers, ballot and campaign materials from the 1950s through the 1980s that offer insight into the evolution of the union. A union label file provides excellent and colorful examples of union labels for bread. Also of interest are the files that document corruption within the baking trade in the early 1960s (See: James Cross; Daniel Motto). Many of these subject files may have been used as research material in the monthly publication of "The Local 3 News." Michael Sandroff's notes for the Local 3's 1967 publication of its history, "Progress Through Unity," can also be found here as can his unpublished memoir "I Paid My Dues."General Files/Correspondence297771960-1969211General Files/Correspondence297761970-1974212General Files/Correspondence297751975-1977213General Files/Correspondence297741978-1979214General Files/Correspondence297731980-1989215By-Laws297721958 , 1964 , 1969 , 1976216By-Laws Committee297711967217History: M. Packet (TWUA)2970119672236Shop StewardMaterial, Class Related Material297001957 , 1966-19692237Strike Ballot29699undated2238Structure Committee2969819722239Summons2969719822240Trustee Reports2969619832241Union Label, Shop Stamps29695undated2242Series VI: Welfare and Pension Fund296731955-1988
Scope and Contents note
This series contains the records of two separate entities, the Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund of Local 51 and the Local 3 Welfare and Pension Fund. With the merger of these two unions in 1973 Harry Lorber became the Chairman of the Board of Trustees for both organizations. The inequity between the two funds was the source of pre-merger negotiation and documents related to this can be found in the general files and correspondence of the early 1970s. Further information about this issue can be found in the papers of Local 51 which are located in Series VII.Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Plan Description and Summary296931984231Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Correspondence and Bills296921972-1976232Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, General Files, Agreements, Financial, Legal, Minutes296911954-1972233Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Affidavits, Pensioners A-E296901988234Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Affidavits, Pensioners F-J296891988235Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Affidavits, Pensioners K-R296881988236Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Affidavits, Pensioners S296871988237Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Affidavits, Pensioners T-Z296861988238Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Financial Statements/Funds296851953-1963239Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Financial Statements/Reports296841964-19722310Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Financial Statements/Reports296831973-19762311Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Financial Statements/Reports296821978-19842312Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Mortgage Title Company296811957-19882313Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Mortgage, Lawrence #1 Corporation296801968-19802314Cake Bakers Union Welfare Fund, Pension Committee/Henry Lorber29679[1960-1969]2315Local 3, Welfare and Pension Fund, General Files/Correspondence29678undated, 1974-19832316Local 3, Welfare and Pension Fund, General Files/Correspondence296771983, 19862317
General note
Materials in German and English .Local 3, Welfare and Pension Fund, Pension Fund Report2967619552318Local 3, Welfare and Pension Fund, Pension Fund Report2967519562319Local 3, Welfare and Pension Fund, Retirement Benefit Plan2967419812320Series VII: General Files296211902-1978
Scope and Contents note
Included in this series are the general files and correspondence of the original six unions (Locals 1, 3, 17, 164, 579) that merged to create Local 3 in 1955 as well as a number of other local unions that subsequently merged with Local 3 including Cake Baker's Union Local 51. Insurance claim forms in English and in German from old Local 3, dating from the turn of the century, are located here and represent the oldest documents in the Collection. Also of note are election leaflets from Local 338 which are in Yiddish. Of particular interest are the merger-related documents, including a file on the proposed alliance between the Bakers Union and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Included are papers that cover the meetings and negotiations that preceded the 1955 merger, the reunification of the International Union, and the merger between Locals 3 and 51. Scope and Contents note
This series contains the souvenir programs of a variety of locals and trade organizations. Photographs and laudatory accounts of union history are here in abundance. Of particular interest are programs related to the Cake Shows which picture some fine examples of the output of the skilled bakers.Local 1: 56th Anniversary Celebration Ball and Cake Parade29620Mar 14, 1942261Local 1: 57th Anniversary296191943262Local 1: 1944 Year Book296181944263Local 1: 1945 Year Book296171945264Local 1: 1946 Year Book296161946265Local 1: 62nd Anniversary Celebration, 1948 Year Book296151948266Local 1: 100th Anniversary296141950267Local 1: 101st Anniversary, Ball and Cake Show296131951268Local 1: 103rd Anniversary Annual Dance and Merger Celebration296121953269Old Local 3 25th Jubilee296111929269aLocal 3, Charter Presentation to Consolidated Bakers Union2961019552610Local 3, First Annual Dance and Cake Exhibit2960919602611Local 3, Diamond Jubilee, 75th Anniversary 2nd Annual Dance and Cake Show2960819612612Local 3, Third Annual Dance and Trade Exhibit2960719622613Local 3, Fourth Annual Entertainment and Dance2960619642614Local 3 Tenth Anniversary Banquet2960519662615Local 3, 13th Anniversary2960419682616Local 3, 15th Anniversary Celebration In Memoriam to Frank Dutto2960319702617Local 3, Merger Celebration Honoring Retiring Secretary-Treasurer Adolf Wohst2960219762618Local 3, Fifth Anniversary Merger Celebration2960119782619Local 22 50th Anniversary2960019362620
